item.description:

Wests Tigers recruit Zane Musgrove has been charged over an incident at Coogee before he has even made his club debut.

Wests Tigers recruit Zane Musgrove has been charged with a number of offences including aggravated indecent assault following a night out at the Coogee Bay ...

item.title: Zane Musgrove signs with Wests Tigers after South Sydney Rabbitohs release - Sporting News AU

The Wests Tigers have added depth to their forward pack with the signing of South Sydney's Zane Musgrove. Musgrove has put pen to paper on a three-year ...

item.title: Souths inspired by GI return - The Advertiser
item.description:
Souths inspired by GI return  The Advertiser

Twenty days after the rugby league world was rocked by news Inglis had been admitted to a mental rehabilitation facility, the inspirational leader looked fresh as he was one of the first to arrive for training at Redfern around 7am. Dressed in a black Souths hoodie and shorts, Inglis completed some cardio work and a weights session underneath the main grandstand before sharing a few laughs with his teammates. While Inglis will not play again this season because of an ACL injury — and won’t be at Suncorp Stadium for Friday night’s blockbuster against the Broncos — coach Michael Maguire said ...

item.title: SuperCoach teams analysis round 24 - The Advertiser
item.description:
SuperCoach teams analysis round 24  The Advertiser

* Cameron Munster - Named to return from an ankle injury for the Storm. * Kalyn Ponga - Early-season cheapie earns a backline spot at the Cowboys, with 12 top-grade players currently injured. * Jarryd Hayne - Lost in all this week’s drama is the fact Hayne is still owned by over 15 per cent. Named but rated “50-50” due to ankle injury. * Sam Burgess - Named for the Rabbitohs despite an ongoing rib issue. Will play prop, which could mean reduced minutes. * Joseph Leilua - Cleared of a serious knee injury and named for the Raiders. LOSERS * Tohu Harris - Sits out another week due to an ongoin...

item.title: Crichton bombs breakaway try - The Advertiser

NRL: Angus Crichton might need to lay off the stickum spray after making a meal of this pass.

item.title: Musgrove out to prove Warriors wrong for snub - The Advertiser
item.description:
Musgrove out to prove Warriors wrong for snub  The Advertiser

The match will give Musgrove an invaluable opportunity to prove the Warriors wrong for failing to give him a trial as a junior in Auckland. “The Warriors were the first team I looked to having grown up in New Zealand, but they didn’t give me a chance,” Musgrove said. “I didn’t even get looked at. “The Rabbitohs were the first ones to give me a chance, so that’s why I took it. “I tried to make (the Warriors), but I probably wasn’t good enough coming through. “It was pretty hard to get into the Warriors back then because they only picked a few players in each age group. “There were just bette...

item.title: Fire or flounder: Madge reads Burgess riot act - The Advertiser
item.description:
Fire or flounder: Madge reads Burgess riot act  The Advertiser

The premiership-winning prop has been left out of Maguire’s 17 for Friday’s NRL season opener against the Wests Tigers at ANZ Stadium. Burgess has fallen hard since establishing himself as one of the game’s best big men during the Bunnies’ drive to the 2014 title. Maguire has shown he has no regard for reputation by naming 20-year-old Zane Musgrove to start in Burgess’s place for round one. Burgess struggled for impact last year as a result of hip and groin injuries but declared himself problem-free heading into 2017. He had an unhappy Charity Shield, dropping the ball with one of his first...

item.title: Dragons to put it on the line - The Australian
item.description:
Dragons to put it on the line  The Australian

The Dragons’ shock defeat to Newcastle not only all but ended their chance of a crucial top-four finish, but left them in danger of being overtaken by ninth-placed Penrith. “It’s time to put it on the line, that’s for sure,” coach Paul McGregor said ahead of his team’s captain’s run yesterday. “We’ve come too far to get it taken away from us. “We still as a group wanted to be in the top four. Last week’s loss put a dent in that, so we’re now at the stage where we’ve got to keep winning to remain in the eight, so it’s hugely important.” McGregor is adamant his men have proven they can defy h...

item.title: NRL SuperCoach study guide: Rabbitohs - The Advertiser
item.description:
NRL SuperCoach study guide: Rabbitohs  The Advertiser

Add to that the Rabbitohs being one of two teams playing all three of the ‘big’ bye rounds and you might want to start taking notes. Cody Walker burst onto the scene last season becoming the ‘Cheapie of the Year’, but can he back up his stellar debut season? Does Rob Jennings slide straight into the 17 after the departures of Kirisome Auva’a and Joe Burgess? Can Adam Reynolds stay healthy and step into the elite keeper category? Let’s take a look. BEST 17 1. Greg Inglis, 2. Alex Johnston, 3. Hymel Hunt, 4. Rob Jennings, 5. Aaron Gray, 6. Cody Walker, 7. Adam Reynolds, 8. Tom Burgess, 9. Rob...

item.title: Rabbitohs find a silver lining - The Australian
item.description:
Rabbitohs find a silver lining  The Australian

“Last year we set out to bring young players through and to the club,” Rabbitohs head of football Shane Richardson said. “It is part of our recruitment policy to bring those young kids through. You’re going to have your ups and downs ... but they give you real hope because they want to be here and they have the interests of the team at heart. “Last year we finished 10th with the (North Sydney) Bears in the NSW Cup and 16th in the NYC (under 20s), and we had 85 players on our books. “This year we have 55 players, we’re currently fifth with the Bears and we’re on the verge of the top eight in...

item.title: NRL player Angus Crichton wants to make learning about Indigenous Australia more accessible - ABC News
item.description:
NRL player Angus Crichton wants to make learning about Indigenous Australia more accessible  ABC News

By Shahni Wellington It's a world away from the lights, crowds and fever of a State of Origin match. But each year since 2015, New South Wales Blues player Angus Crichton has boarded a tiny plane and flown 540 kilometres from Darwin to his second home, Arnhem Land's Lake Evella, to continue a friendship with two community members that dates back to high school. It's an experience that has now inspired him use his footballing platform to educate Australians about a shared Indigenous history. "These two boys are Yolngu boys from Lake Evella and obviously English is their second language," Cri...

item.title: Actions of Rabbitohs' Zane Musgrove had 'hallmarks of domestic violence': magistrate - ABC News
item.description:
Actions of Rabbitohs' Zane Musgrove had 'hallmarks of domestic violence': magistrate  ABC News

A Sydney magistrate has blasted South Sydney NRL player Zane Musgrove, saying he was "no different to a bus driver or anyone else" and should not receive special treatment, as he pleaded guilty to damaging property. The 22-year-old rugby league player was convicted in the Downing Centre Local Court over an incident at a home in Zetland earlier this year in which he pulled a gate off its hinges following an argument with his girlfriend. His solicitor Christopher Watson said his client "opened the gate in frustration" when his girlfriend told him to leave, after she had asked him to pick her ...

item.title: Burgess claim rocks Rabbitohs - The Australian
item.description:
Burgess claim rocks Rabbitohs  The Australian

It seems hard to believe South Sydney’s preparations for their sudden-death final against St George Illawarra could get any worse. Amid allegations that Sam Burgess’s social media accounts are at the centre of a sexting scandal, last night it emerged that prop Zane Musgrove would face court on the domestic violence charges next week. The Rabbitohs are officially in damage control. Of most concern is the suggestion that Burgess may be under investigation over allegations stretching back to May ­following a complaint made by a 23-year-old woman. The club last night announced they had appointe...

item.title: No finger? No problem. How an amputation set Angus Crichton up for his Origin debut - ABC News
item.description:
No finger? No problem. How an amputation set Angus Crichton up for his Origin debut  ABC News

By Julia Holman How far would you go to follow your passion? For South Sydney rugby league forward, Angus Crichton, it meant giving up a digit. Crichton had his finger amputated after suffering a ruptured tendon that refused to heal. Just six months later he made his Origin debut for New South Wales against Queensland in front of a packed MCG. "[It's] pretty full on stuff but I'm pretty stoked with the decision I've made," he told 7.30. 'Oh, I've actually cut my finger off. It can freak you out' He may never have played Origin if he hadn't had his finger amputated. Despite seven operations ...
